sentences: He was a leading influence on British musical life in the first half of the 20th century.
Hugh Allen was born in Reading, Berkshire, the youngest of the seven children of Rebecca, née Stevens (1836–1919) and John Herbert Allen (1834–1905).
Hugh Allen was born in Reading, Berkshire, the youngest of the seven children of Rebecca, née Stevens (1836–1919) and John Herbert Allen (1834–1905).
He won an organ scholarship to Christ's College, Cambridge, graduating BA from Cambridge in 1895.
He became cathedral organist at St Asaph Cathedral and then Ely Cathedral, before, in 1901, becoming organist of New College, Oxford, where he revitalised the musical life of the University.
In 1907 he was appointed conductor of the Bach Choir in London and in 1913 he shared the Leeds Festival with Artur Nikisch and Sir Edward Elgar.
In 1907 he was appointed conductor of the Bach Choir in London and in 1913 he shared the Leeds Festival with Artur Nikisch and Sir Edward Elgar.
In 1918 Sir Walter Parratt resigned the professorship of music at Oxford, and Allen succeeded him.
section: == Oxford and the Royal College of Music ==

sentences: But when Sir Hubert Parry died later in the year Allen was appointed director of the Royal College of Music in London, and Oxford thought it would lose him.
section: == Oxford and the Royal College of Music ==

sentences: He kept his rooms at New College, and for another seven years conducted the Oxford Bach Choir.
section: == Oxford and the Royal College of Music ==

sentences: He retired from the college in 1937, but his years of work came to fruition in 1944 when Oxford founded a Faculty of Music.

Allen received many honours, being knighted in the 1920 King's Birthday Honours List and appointed a Commander of the Royal Victorian Order (CVO) in the 1926 New Years Honours List.

Besides receiving his Oxford doctorate he was awarded honorary doctorates by the universities of Cambridge (1925), Reading (1938), Sheffield (1926), and Berlin.

He was an honorary fellow of Christ's College, Cambridge (1926); and in 1937 was Master of the Worshipful Company of Musicians.
He was an honorary fellow of Christ's College, Cambridge (1926); and in 1937 was Master of the Worshipful Company of Musicians.
On 17 February 1946, Allen was knocked down by a motorcyclist in Oxford.
He died of his injuries three days later at Radcliffe Infirmary, aged 76.
On 2 April 1902, he married Edith Winifred (1877–1966) and together they had one daughter and one son.
